Avoiding impurities might be the wrong idea in the first place. I got a bucket in my frontyard where i use to clean housebuilders equipment. Over time the water went white with impurities that range from sand and gravel to molekular size. Also pH seems to have risen to 8-10ish, this stuff makes your skin soapy on touch. When winter came over the last weeks, the white water only froze at about -3°C and it froze cleanly from the top down, driving the impurities in front of the ice. Never seen such clear ice before. So actually impurities might help in evening out the cristallizing process. I think this might have to do with lowering overall freezing temperature, thus dust particles tend not to be starting points of cristallization but rather slow down the process and make it more clean.

I believe the reason for formation of "bubbles" is completely different than most people here say.
Ice has lower density than water. When we freeze it, it expands in all directions. We can all agree on that.
In the freezer ice starts forming from all sides, compressing liquid water in the center. Then this water turns to ice, expanding, cracking under tension and breaking the structure around itself.
You can clearly see a bulge from this expansion on top of every test cup.
That explains why mixing works - this way, water can freeze simultaneously at all points since there's no difference in temperature. Popsicles are also formed from untreated water carrying dirt from roofs, yet they are completely clear - that's because they gradually grow in size and the ice from droplets of water expands outside, leaving the core undamaged. Some ice generators use that principle as well.

Here's how you make a block of ice as big as you'd like and have it be completely, 100%, bubble free and clear:

slowly drip water into a container as it is in the freezer. If you have a chest freezer you can even manage this without having to drill any holes by simply having a hose clamped between the lid and filling up the gaps with some isolating material. If you have a big enough chest freezer you could make a seriously big block of clear ice to use for ice sculpting. You have to experiment a bit to get the water drip rate right though.

By doing it like this there will always be a place for the gas to disappear into as you are forcing the ice to form from the bottom upwards.

Water sublimates, i.e. evaporates as a solid.  This means that ice creates bubbles in liquid above it.  Any ice above liquid water will trap the bubbles which will freeze into the liquid when it freezes. Water forms spires that shoot out from the top until it hits the bottom, and these crystals are random, like lightning bolts. The cloudy area is full of these crystal spires all pilled over each other.


There isn't a lot you can do about it. One way is to heat the bottom and super freeze the top, that prevents the ice from ever forming ice spires, and you just lift the blocks off the top as they form. Another thing you can do is vibrate the water as it forms as it will destroy the spire like crystal structure before it can fully form.

Slowly freezing ice is the way to go - The clear inches, I reckon, are as a result of the unfrozen, deeper water buffering the 'slowly' freezing upper layers, at the point that the insulation of the container is overcome (I estimate 40-50% of the way from the top down), the freezing rate suddenly increases.

I'd suggest logging (perhaps at multiple depths) the temperature overtime (probes and arduino) to see whether this sudden freezing ramp down in temperature occurs. Alternatively, I am not sure how one would slow freezing at home, perhaps some electronic relay that's able to engage and disengage a chest freezer at home to do a big block of ice, suitable for, perhaps sculpture - You'd be electronically slowing the freeze rate engaging the freezer as required to get the best freeze ramp over time.

There is a very easy way to get clear ice and you will get 100% clear ice every time. Take a tank and fill it with water. Get two pumps to circulate the water constantly. Put the tank into a freezer. This how professional ice-makers and sculptors get their clear ice.

I've worked on commercial ice machines and there are a few that make clear ice and most make clouded ice. The ones that make clear ice have the evaporator at 32 degrees F. Water flowing over this evaporator produces a slower freeze giving you a clear cube. Other ice machines make clouded cubes with water flowing over the evaporator also but these evaporators operate at temps significantly colder than 32 degrees F.

There are a couple different things to help make clear ice.
First, let your water sit in an open container overnight or longer. Many of the gases you mentioned will escape.
Second, as others have mentioned, the faster it freezes, the more bubbles you will get.
Finally, as you 'sort of' demonstrated and mentioned in this video, once the surface of the ice freezes, gases can no longer escape.

I actually made ice sculptures at one of my jobs by using silicon molds. They were very large, about 15-20 gallons of water to fill. I did some research myself in an effort to make them more clear, and also found that many methods people rave about don't necessarily work. What did end up working best for me was to occasionally open the freezer and break the ice on the surface and stir the water around a little. This way it froze from the bottom and edges, the surface being last, allowing gases to escape the entire time.

The secret to getting clear ice, as you discovered, is to force the ice to freeze in only one direction. The cooler method works best for this. But to get perfectly clear ice, you need to remove the cooler from the freezer before the whole volume of water freezes. When the top of the water has turned to ice, but the bottom is still water, the top ice will be perfectly clear.

you're supposed to use 2 containers. one inside the other. on the bottom of the inner container you drill holes in the bottom to let the water that hasn't frozen yet containing the dissolved gases and impurities be pushed into the outer container. also you're supposed to suspend the inner container so that the bottom is several inches from the bottom of the outer container. then you freeze it until most of the inner container is frozen. you'll have a large chunk/slab of perfectly clear ice and a container of really cold water that you could use to start the process over again with if you wanted to make multiple slabs. there are videos on youtube demonstrating how it works if you wanna look them up.

the best way to make crystal clear - ice, is to freeze the water with pump to keep the water flowing at a slow pace, inside a smooth, stainless steel container. As the water bit by bit freezes at the bottom, any sort of impurities like bubbles will be pushed up until there is not enough water to circulate. this leaves around 10 cm of unfrozen water depensing on your pump, but you will have a crystal clear ice for your cocktail...

Movement is key in getting clear ice. However, there are little contraptions you can buy to make clear sphere ice cubes in your freezer.

The white area in the center of an ice cube is a buildup of impurities, mostly sediment and trapped air bubbles. Because freezing starts from the outside in, these materials are pushed to the center of the cube while the pure area remains clear.

Companies who do make perfectly clear ice blocks, do so by putting water into large containers, and have a constant water jet cycling the water. This makes it so that the water is always moving, so if any air bubbles form, the are taken to the top. The downside to this though, is that since the water is moving, the freezing process takes significantly longer, but you do get crystal clear ice.

How to make clear ice- Tipsy Bartender. . . . You're welcome!

Freezing is a purification action. As the ice forms, the amount of liquid water gets smaller, but the amount of dissolved gasses stays the same. This causes the concentration of the dissolved gasses to increase. Eventually, the remaining liquid water becomes saturated with dissolved gasses and they start precipitating out as bubbles. But in all the cases here, there is a seal of ice preventing the bubbles from escaping so they just get locked into the continually forming ice. In the plastic (and one glass) containers, the water is freezing from all directions so the precipitated bubbles form in the middle. In the cooler, because of the top-down freezing direction, the bubbles were trapped below the clear ice.

As far as degassing goes, the one that had the best chance was the one in the glass bowl. Water absorbs air very readily, and anyone with an aquarium knows pouring water puts a lot of air into water. But, the one in the glass bowl was still destined to fail simply because the water was absorbing gasses just from the top surface. Had he sealed the top surface there might have been a chance at a successful freeze as long as the vessel maintained integrity (i.e. didn't shatter).

I worked on a project where we froze 650 gallons of water in tanks and had to keep the ice as optically clear as possible. We elected to use the top-down method. Because of the 10% volumetric expansion of water to ice we also had to allow for excess water to drain out, so we used a fitting at the bottom of the tank attached to a vertical pipe for overflow. This gave us a port into the bottom of the tank that we used to connect to a circulation and degassing unit on the bottom of the tank. The degasser would work very hard until the first skin of ice across the top, then the amount of gas that could be removed was controlled by how much ice formed. It would take a few months to freeze, but we ended up with a block of ice 3-4 feet thick that you could read a newspaper through.

I can't claim to have tried yet but I think you are almost there!  At one point I was interested in how to do this and watched a number of videos.  I have noticed two similar methods that appear to work quite well and you basically did one of them.  They both involve using a cooler to control the direction if freezing.  One is freezing a block like you did and just remove the portion that is not clear at the bottom.  The second way is to suspend some form of ice cube tray or mold in water in the cooler, the container for the ice must be open at the bottom.  Let the ice freeze until it has frozen the depth of your tray or mold, then remove.  If you search YouTube for "clear ice" these methods are used in several of the top results.  Vibrating or circulating the water also sounds interesting, would be interested to see if that worked.

Commercial ice companies use a combination of distilled water and a small low power pump (also vibration) to make clear ice. They submerge the pump towards the top or bottom or vibrate while freezing the water. The movement causes the impurities to rise to the top while freezing leaving clear ice behind from bottom up. Towards the end there should be a small dent with water at the top. They then scoop out the water in the dent, fill with fresh distilled water and allow to freeze. You could also skip the fill step and just cut the top of the ice to be even.

Ok, a couple things.

First, the best way to get CRYSTAL clear ice is to ironically enough, prevent crystal formation. That is why glass is clear. As we know from your ammonium nitrate crystal growth videos, the best way to cause crystals is to slowly cool a non moving solution to give crystals time to form. It is the same with the water. The best way to prevent crystals from forming is to keep the liquid water moving across the surface of the freezing water. Professional ice sculptors use a small pump to keep the water moving. Ice makers pump water across the evaporator plate that cools and freezes the ice. That is why your ice chest method made the most clear ice. As the ice was forming it was only able to be cooled from the top, and the rest of the water was too warm for it to freeze, so in essence you were cooling it too fast to form crystals. But as the rest of the water cooled down to near freezing the crystals were able to grow throughout and that caused the ice to not be clear.

The second thing is a video idea. I was wondering if you could do a video where you freeze two identical containers of water side by side in a freezer. One would start out as hot water, and one would be cold water. That way, we could finally get video proof of which one freezes first when they are sitting still.

To make clear ice use a clinebell machine. The clinebell is 3 basic parts when it comes down to it. A cold plate on the bottom, the water bin in the middle and a water pump on top. So as you may have already imagined the ice freezes from the bottom to the top while the pump circulates water over the newest (top) freezing layer. "wouldn’t the water pump eventually freeze?” Yes, the water in the pumps eventually freezes but you can easliy turn it off

I have a possible idea for getting completely clear ice. Seal a piece of acrylic to the top of the cooler with Proto putty, then invert the cooler. The acrylic will allow cold in slowly from the bottom, but the cooler will insulate the rest of it. This will allow the water to freeze slowly, and will allow the gases to escape  the water into the air gap inside the cooler. That should let the water freeze from the bottom up completely clear.

ATTENTION TKOR....I can speak from experience. When I was a young teenager, I worked in an Ice House/Factory.  We made many 350 pound ice blocks daily.  To achieve clear ice, we would fill the vats with water then attach brass rods that bubbled air through the water from near the bottom of the vat. Once there was ice formed around the outside (3-4 inches)  we would pull the lids, remove the rods, vacuum the remaining water out and then put fresh water in.  The end result was crystal clear ice around the outside and only the core had air bubbles.  Get a minnow bucket air bubbler for bait fishing.  Maybe make a container that bubbles air from the bottom i.e.   no rods.

Having watched many ice sculpture videos, the way they make their ice clear is by freezing it while the water is in continuous circulation. IE: water jet just below the water line. Having seen many of these videos where TKOR is trying to get clear ice, im sure a video or two must have been seen by now. If not, highly suggest. Also note some rivers who freeze over clear are also in continuous motion as they freeze over so never perfectly still.  Freezing water in a 'still state' makes the water expand and crack as the freezing ice touches the gradually freezing water. same principle as putting an ice cube in water, when it crack your ice cube gets whiter or less clear. Try using a method where the water is still in motion throughout its freezing process and you might get a better result.
